Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I would like to thank everybody who voted for me in the Scottish election and the many people who helped my campaign.I congratulate Jenni Minto on her election and wish her well in her job of representing the people of Argyll and Bute at Holyrood.The following is an open letter from John Gurr, chairperson of the Rest and Be Thankful Campaign group, to Transport Scotland#s chief executive, Roy Brannen, and director of roads, Hugh Gillies, in response to a follow-up email following a meeting held with officials from the transport agency last month. Dear Roy and Hugh,I am writing in response to an official Transport Scotlandemail to the Rest and Be ThankfulCampaign on April  , where you have sought to answer several questions posed by us at our meeting with your officials and in subsequent emails to you both. We are hugely disappointed by this response and its apparent contradictions.We asked for a permanent solution within the next three years. The email states: #We are not waiting for anything and are pushing on with work at pace#, yet your actions since the August landslide have only created delay.Creating  options for consultation in November , this, we believe, is a time-wasting exercise. Five further options for consultation in March. We strongly believe there are only three real options, with studies on these completed in your  report. Conducting a geological survey which will take eighteen months to complete, a process that could have started last August, assuming you had not conducted such surveys in .We have asked for temporary use of the forestry road, away from the threats posed by landsides. It also states: #We were clear without that information we are not certain the forestry track in its current form is safe for use.# Yet we would argue you already have a Transerv report produced in  by Balfour Beatty and Mouchal Services Ltd for TS which suggested the forestry road could be upgraded in  to  weeks. How did Transerv arrive at this conclusion without a study of the ground conditions being done in advance This situation should be considered a safety, economic and social emergency, cutting through the red tape of consultation and delay. It further declares: #We understand first-hand the delay that can be caused by procedural challenge…there needs to be a careful balancing of accelerating development and procedural risk in order to ensure that we do not end up in the courts.#While we understand the need for the right balance of speed and consultation, we think the safety risks, costs incurred by business and damage to the economy of Argyll, should create the conditions for emergency action, delivering what should be a simple road realignment. This is not HS, we are not asking to blight the countryside, or people#s homes, you do not have whole communities ready to challenge fixing the crisis at RABT.What we want cannot be worse than the damage already inflicted on the hillside without consultation. If you fixed the Rest, we will all be thankful.The following questions still have not been answered in TS#s official reply or in recent press statements:We are business people and understand the need for safe environments, effective procedures, timely management, and cost control, but what we have experienced over the past year does not give us confidence you will address the concerns we have.We are not looking for you to defend your approach, what matters to us is the action taken to bring timescales down and resolve the problem within the next parliament. We are simply asking you to rethink your approach, look at how your team can cut through this #business as usual# process and appoint someone who can find a way to realign two kilometres of the A safely within the next three years.By challenging your approach, we are hoping to see that after nearly a year of delay and ersion, there is a recognition of the cost impact to business, the signicant safety concerns, and that this will continue to blight Argyll as a place to live, work, and invest in until a permanent solution is delivered.We will be working with the relevant politicians post elections and will continue to campaign for a change in approach. We would be happy to discuss what can be done to overcome any constraints you have to deliver a solution quickly and resolve the crisis at the RABT.We stand at a once-in-a-generation crossroads.Earlier this week, a thought-provoking poem, ACCEPTABLE  by the Anonymous Mother # judged for needing a food bank to feed her child # started a nationwide debate about whether the world#s fth richest country should need food banks to feed children.This conversation needed to happen as our food bank crisis has become critical.Last year food banks in the Trussell Trust#s network handed out , emergency food parcels for children in the UK. This surely cannot be acceptable.However, fate has given us a rare opportunity, as history shows us that the best time to create a brighter future is after times of great darkness.The pandemic has been the most devastating event to hit our country since the Second World War, but it also brought out the very best of our nation.We recognised our real community heroes, we protected the vulnerable, we didn#t stand by when kids went hungry.But now, as we prepare to wake up from the pandemic nightmare, millions of British families still cannot afford food on their table.As the Anonymous Mother poetically says # it doesn#t need to be this way.In , Britain woke up to its new dawn at a similar crossroads # go back to the old broken way, or use this golden opportunity to make things better.That great generation chose hope, and created a better, fairer society for all # including founding the NHS.This pandemic has been our generation#s darkest hour. This is now our new dawn, our choice. Will we choose the old broken way, or use this golden opportunity to eradicate hunger in the UK I urge you to do just one thing today, and that is to seek out the poem that started all of this, and reflect.If, afterwards, you agree with me and the hundreds of thousands of other supporters of the Trussell Trust, that we can do better, join us as we collectively create a #hunger free future#.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.For the latest on government guidance, retailers should visit gov.uk workingsafely‘We ensure measures are effective’PAUL BAINES, MANAGER,STEPHEN JOSEPH THEATRE, SCARBOROUGHThe curtain goes up again at Stephen Joseph Theatre on May  while Eat Me Cafe, in the bar area, and a gt shop, in the foyer, will also reopen.“We were open for nearly six months of last year. We did a huge amount of work including introducing a one-way system, social distancing measures and putting down markers,” said theatre manager Paul Baines. “One of the biggest challenges was getting people in and out safely.“We have to ensure the measures are genuine and effective and they are visible. Visible reassurance is important for customer confidence.“It is a juggling act because you have to balance creating a too clinical atmosphere with offering a unique theatre experience.”The theatre has been awarded the VisitEngland We’re Good to Go industry standard mark, signying that it adheres to government and public health COVID- guidance, also approved by UK Theatre Seat Safety.‘People need care and pampering’ROSIE FRASER, OWNER,THAT ROSIE GLOW, EDINBURGHAlongside familiar COVID- safety measures, Rosie Fraser has introduced a new service called “Silent Treatment”.“We love a good chat but we also understand some people prefer not to,” said Rosie, whose beauty salon opened in .“Clients can see the service as soon as they look at the online booking menu and add it with whatever treatments they are having.“We still carry out a full consultation and then let them just relax.”Also in place are bespoke engraved screens between stations, extra time for cleaning, screening forms for track and trace, PPE and sanitising measures. Rosie emphasises that it is safety with style!Members of the seven-strong team are carrying out rapid COVID- tests at home thanks to the UK Government asymptomatic testing initiative.“We have exciting plans for this year in expanding. COVID- and lockdown has reaffirmed how much people need care and pampering to feel good.”‘Trade boost from vaccine confidence’JOHN LAVERY, OWNER,FISH CITY, BELFASTInvestment has helped Fish City in Belfast continue operating. The award-winning seafood restaurant extended its seating, installed outdoor heating and started a delivery service. Since reopening for outdoor dining, it has been doing a brisk trade bolstered by confidence in the vaccine programme. Reopening indoors is scheduled to start on May .“We created a dining room upstairs with a completely dferent feel,” said John, who owns the restaurant with his we Grainne. Safety processes include a digital thermometer mounted at the door which all staff and customers are required to pass before entering. Anyone recording a high temperature is refused admission.Hand sanitisers are also available. Kitchen and front of house staff are required to wear masks and wash their hands regularly. Tables and chairs are cleaned rigorously after every diner. The restaurant’s commitment to the safety is also seen in its recognition as COVID- Compliant by Tourism NI.‘We worked hard to train all the team’MEURIG JONES, LOCATION MANAGER,PORTMEIRION VILLAGE, PORTMEIRION“If I could do cartwheels, I would” is one retail chief’s response to welcoming the public back.“When we saw the first trickle of people coming back last month, it was lovely,” enthused village location manager MeurigJones. “Portmeirion needs people here.“It’s lovely but it isn’t what it should be without people appreciating it. It’s easier this year in that it was such a new thing when we opened in July.“We had to do a lot of work to train the staff into a new way of working. We’re constantly improving and we’re learning as we go on.”App orders and one-way systems will ensure ongoing safety. Outside seating, pods and marquee are also available. Misting machines, meanwhile, will keep hotels“squeaky clean – safe for staff and guests”.Meurig added: “There’s hand sanitiser outside every shop and we ask people to wear masks indoors, but not outside.”

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.As the anniversary of the battle of St Valéry-en-Caux approaches, an international search has been launched to uncover the identity of a fallen hero.The soldier of the st Highland Division evaded capture during the infamous Second World War battle, in which almost  men from Kintyre fought, but would later be discovered and now rests in an unnamed grave.Days after the mass evacuations at Dunkirk, thousands of men from the st Highland Division remained on mainland Europe supporting their French allies. As German troops advanced through Normandy, the st fought valiantly, protecting French citizens, hoping evacuation by sea would be forthcoming.On June  , German tanks surrounded the ision at the French fishing port of St Valéry. This, alongside a curtain of heavy fog, made the long-awaited flotilla rescue unviable and they were forced to surrender. Those who were not killed in the fighting were captured as prisoners of war and marched to camps in Eastern Europe, where they remained for five gruelling years.Following the commemorations to mark the th anniversary of the battle last June, a remarkable story has emerged. One brave soldier miraculously evaded capture and was taken in by a French family who hid him from the occupying German forces.#We were contacted by Monsieur Patrick Prieur, a -year-old St Valéry resident whose grandparents and father remained in the town during the entirety of the war. He told us the story of the escapee and the tragedy that befell him,# said Dr Claire Armstrong, chief executive of Legion Scotland.#As we approach the st anniversary of the battle, we hope to identy this Scottish hero, give him the recognition he deserves and bring peace to his family.#Patrick Prieur recalled the tale his late father told him: #A soldier from the st Highland Division was hidden by a family in the village. They bonded and the family learned he was a married man with a we and two daughters waiting for him tohome.#For several weeks, the soldier remained hidden but, regretfully, he was eventually discovered by German troops and marched through the town to the municipal cemetery.#After being forced to dig his own grave, he was positioned against the cemetery wall and shot. His death deeply upset the townspeople, who had been aware of his hiding, and especially my father, who was only  at the time.#In later years, the Franco-British military cemetery was built and his body was moved there. His grave is marked as #Known unto God# and my father and other villagers tended to it for decades after the war ended.#Monsieur Prieur added: #My father had been gted a piece of paper on which the soldier#s name was written, #Keller Len Scott#, and this became his prized possession. He desperately wanted to find the soldier#s family to tell them what had happened to their beloved and where he was laid to rest, but having very little information, he struggled.#In  my father passed away and, being eager to finish what he started, I recently contacted Poppyscotland and the Highland Reserve Forces# and Cadets# Association to ask for help.#Michelle McKearnon, head of engagement at the Highland Reserve Forces# and Cadets# Association, said: #We started to do our own research to unearth the fallen soldier#s identity but only got so far. We believe the name order on the piece of paper may have been written in military fashion, with the surname preceding any given names, so the family name might be Keller.#We#re now at an impasse, struggling to find additional information through our own resources, so we need the knowledge of the wider community to continue our efforts.#Dr Armstrong added: #We are urging anyone who believes they know of or has any information about our #Unknown Soldier#, no matter how small, to get in touch.#This brave man fought valiantly for his country and to repay our debt to him for his service would be an honour, not only for Legion Scotland as custodians of remembrance, but for his family, Monsieur Prieur#s father, the people of St Valéry and, ultimately, for all the #unknown soldiers# who sacriced their lives for us.#Anyone with information that could help identy the soldier should visit poppyscotland.org.uk stvalery

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.A classic British racing yacht and her crew were saved from being dashed onto the rocks of the Mull of Kintyre on Saturday night by Campbeltown#s leboats during a six-hour rescue operation.The yacht was competing in the Scottish Islands Peak Race.The rudder of the ft-long Sceptre had broken and Force Six winds from the northwest were driving her onto clfs below the lighthouse.Campbeltown#s Severn-class leboat was launched with the inshore leboat following. They did notto the harbour until after pm with the casualty in tow.The following day, Sceptre skipper Tom Smith praised the hard work and efficiency of the Campbeltown leboat crews.Diver Robert Lamont, a member of the leboat crew the night before, went in and removed the damaged rudder ready for Sceptre to be towed by tug to Troon, the finish of the race.The race sails from Oban to Mull, Jura and Arran then Troon, stopping at each island for a team of runners to complete a hill race.Sceptre, with a crew of four, was carrying the boys# team from Glenalmond School, Perth.She had run aground the night before entering Craighouse, Jura. Everything looked fine on the yacht, which was built in Argyll at Alexander Robertson#s Holy Loch yard to compete in the America#s Cup of .#As a precaution, we did not have the boys on board for the tough leg round the Mull of Kintyre to Arran,# said crew member Roger Finbow.#They haven#t missed the race they were on board Blue Damsel, carrying the girls# team.#The decision proved a wise move as not only did the rudder come loose leaving the yacht with no steering, it was flapping wildly and in danger of damaging the hull.As a precaution, the leboat crew put a heavy-duty pump on board but this was not needed.HMS Dragon broke off her sea trials to come to the aid of Sceptre. The Type  Clyde-built destroyer stood by until the leboat arrived.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOCalls were mounting earlier this week for a Scottish Office decision on the proposed ferry link between Campbeltown and Northern Ireland.The Scottish Office has been considering a business plan for state-owned Caledonian MacBrayne to operate the link with Ballycastle in Northern Ireland since the beginning of February.The company needs Scottish Office permission to become involved in the project.But concern is growing that unless a decision is made soon the necessary harbour work at Campbeltown will not start until it is too late for the service to begin next year.Two Campbeltown ambulance men were among six from Argyll recently presented with long service and good conduct medals by the Duke of Argyll.Ronnie Hamilton and Malcolm Black travelled to Oban for the presentation, carried out by the Duke on behalf of HM Queen.The medals are not awarded automatically but are made on the recommendation of a special .The Duke told the ambulance men: #What you do is not a profession, it is a vocation.#He also paid tribute to their families, pointing out the ambulance men worked anti-social hours for long periods at a time.FIFTY YEARS AGOCampbeltown was #switched on# to colour television on Tuesday by the town#s new Provost, William Craig, in his first official engagement.The service has been brought to Campbeltown by Redfusion, the firm which pipes television to several thousand subscribers from its mast at Crosshill Farm.The firm#s Scottish general manager Mr Colin Payne said that Redfusion offers a public service of which they were proud.#We looked at the television problems here. There were just BBC and STV and occasionally Ulster in the town.#We said can we bring to Campbeltown the full range of colour programmes which are available where and the answer to that was #yes#.#There are now six programmes on the system. There aren#t many places in the country which can receive this.#ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOAn English steam liner which called in here for bait one day last week had full bunkers and a plentul reserve of coal in ious corners. She had gone to Ostende for the fuel.A further restriction of the gas supply in the burgh comes into force on Saturday night. The hours during which there will be reduced and normal pressure respectively are given in advertisement.The local branch of the Miners# Union opened a subscription list this week for the purpose of starting a communal soup kitchen. It is not intended, of course, to confine the benefits of the scheme to miners or their dependents. Over £ has already been raised and the committee intend to publish the list of subscriptions next week.A welcome break in our comparative isolation from the mainland was made at the beginning of the week when the steamer Kinloch made a special run to the upper reaches, with mail, passengers and cargo.Many merchants, not only in Campbeltown but at Carradale and the west of Arran ports, were carrying very low stocks and this run was not made a day too soon to prevent absolute scarcity of not a few necessities.Flour, for one thing, was running very short, and the new supplies got by bakers were very much-needed.Alcohol is again tipped as a likely rival to petrol. The new motor fuel is being produced by the Distillers Company Ltd and consists of a mixture of  per cent of alcohol,  per cent of benzole and  per cent of paraffin. The idea of using alcohol is not new, but a fatal obstacle has been the unwillingness of the government to release its hold upon alcohol and permit it to be used for commercial purposes.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I have been reading a lot of reports and letters in national and local newspapers about the problems experienced at the Rest and Be Thankful.I have no doubt that those charged with keeping the trunk road operational and safe for drivers are doing their best in the circumstances.However, there now seems to be an acceptance in Transport Scotland that a new solution has to be found.In a letter to the press, George Allan points out that the -mile route from Strathlachlan to Colintraive and the eight miles between Ormidale and Tighnabruaich were designed and constructed in  or  years.I was a member of the survey and design team on these routes. I was also involved in the construction of  miles of the A between Perth and Inverness in  years. These civil engineering schemes demonstrate what can be achieved when there is real political will and commitment to prioritise projects.I realise Transport Scotland has its own procedures for appointing consultants for the design processes and there are detailed environmental impact assessments to be done. It does, however, seem to me that its programming of the Rest and Be Thankful improvement is completely lacking in ambition.As a former director of roads and transport in Highland, perhaps I may be permitted to comment on the long-term solution.I would saythere are no geological features found on the other side of the glen which will cause a repeat of current problems, then the construction of a new road in ersion would cause less disruption to traffic than trying to form landslip shelters or tunnels adjacent to the existing carriageway.The main thing though is for Transport Scotland and their political masters to just get on with it.This week, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulancemarks its eighth anniversary – after a year like no other.Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, our Helimed crews have never missed a beat maintaining our emergency helicopter air ambulance service across Scotland#s mainland and island communities. In fact we#ve enhanced our service with the launch of a new aircraft – Helimed  in Aberdeen last year – which has already had a huge impact on pre-hospital care in the Grampian, Highland and island regions.In our busiest year ever, our aircrew have endured challenging working conditions, with additional procedures and cumbersome protective and safety equipment as they go about an already dficult and stressful job.But they#re not complaining – this is what the Scottish public ask of them, to save and improve lives, wherever the need arises, and they fulfil their role with courage and pride.Our exemplary performance during this national crisis has been a tribute to how far SCAA has come in just eight years and I, for one, am immensely proud of what the SCAA team has achieved.But our operational teams are acutely aware that we are only able to provide this critical service, thanks to the continued public donations which you have maintained throughout these dficult times. So you are the real heroes in our charity.SCAA is the people#s helicopter – funded by the people of Scotland, for the people of Scotland – and our two frontline aircraft are stood by ready to help you, your family, your friends, colleagues, neighbours or anyone in your community when you most need us.As we mark our eighth birthday on May , we are asking the people of Scotland,they can, to support us into the future. Any donation, however small, to celebrate our anniversary will help to save a le – just like the numerous lives we have already saved over almost , missions.SCAA vows to continue to transform emergency care in Scotland, particularly to our rural and island communities, with your support. Thank you.As a coalition of leading providers of care and support to vulnerable children and young people, we congratulate all MSPs on their election and welcome the consensus there is between the major political parties to tackle the growing mental health crisis in our young people.We have for some time raised concerns over a potential lost generation of vulnerable children and young people, whose mental health is being impacted even further by the Covid- pandemic.There have been dramatically increased waiting times for mental health treatment during lockdown.In December , for example,  per cent of children and young people had been waiting more than a year for specialist treatment, compared with . per cent in , a truly frightening statistic.A commitment by MSPs to focus on mental health, increasing investment in support services and intervention strategies, must be a priority for this parliament, giving our young people the care and support they need, when they need it.The frightening statistics on the deteriorating mental health of many young people presents a compelling case for a radical new plan for our struggling mental health services and for a national crusade to address what is a mental health pandemic, underpinned by considerably greater resourcing.This is a crisis we can overcome, but it will require a similar energy and commitment to that demonstrated for Covid-we are to achieve this and prevent many young people giving up on their futures.At sight loss charity RNIB Scotland, we are concerned the Covid- crisis might have impacted on people who are blind and partially sighted, many of whom are older.We would like to highlight the emotional reassurance and practical help we offer during the coronavirus lockdown and its aftermath.Covid has eclipsed all other health news in the past year but  people still start to lose their sight in Scotland every week. Add to that stress over Covid and the lockdowns and there could be more people needing support and reassurance.Our Need to Talk telephone counselling service remains available in Argyll and Bute and the Western Highlands for anyone diagnosed with sight loss, as well as families, friends and carers.Losing your sight can be devastating news to take in. But our trained helpers can support you in coming to terms with your condition and finding the way forward.The uncertainty during the Covid lockdown over access to basic shopping and medication, a lack of information in accessible formats, the social isolation, the barriers to being guided because of social distancing # these have all added to and compounded the mental and emotional stress people are experiencing.But we want people with sight loss to know they are not alone and that help is available.To contact the Need to Talk service, phone the RNIB Helpline on    or email needtotalk@rnib.org.uk

title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: bbcs-money-nothing-salvages-items-kinwegar-recycling-centre-wallyford
story: Salvage superhero Sarah Moore was at the East Lothian Council-run site at Kinwegar recently to pick up unwanted goods, give them a new lease of le and turn them into cash for their original owners.The presenter spoke to three East Lothian men ndash two from Musselburgh and one from Elphinstone ndash who arrived at the skips to dispose of the three items.They were delighted to hand them over to her and appear on the programme, which was aired on BBC last month.Michael Clague, the owner of the four-man tent, from Musselburgh, said it was ldquopast its use-by date.He said: ldquoIrsquom just glad the tent is going to be recycled as it was sitting in our garage for some time.Sarah took it to award-winning bag maker Neil Wragg, who turned the old tent into  tote bags, which were sold to people all over the country via social media.Sarah visited the Honest Toun to hand over pound to Michael, who said he would use the cash for a homecoming for his son, who was at sea, and donate some to the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation to help with its charity work.Another Musselburgh man, Alan, was getting ready to throw away a glass-topped coffee table. He and his partner felt it might not now be safe with grandchildren around the house.Sarah took the ldquoretro restoration project to East London-based, award-winning wallpaper, textile and surface designer Daniel Heath, who transformed the table with a custom screenprint design, and spray etch pattern on new toughened glass.Sarah again visited the original owner at his home in Musselburgh to hand over pound profit after the tablersquos sale to a furniture and interior shop in Northumberland. Alan said he planned to treat his grandchildren to a day out with the money he received.An old miniature greenhouse, brought to the centre by George, from Elphinstone, and believed to be an lsquoapprenticersquo piece dating from the s, was rescued to be worked on by Sarah herself at her West Sussex base.ldquoItrsquos a shame to put it in the skip but Irsquom trying to clear out, George said.Sarah went on to turn it into ldquoa vintage greenhouse with a bit of quirkiness by adding new panes of clear and coloured perspex to create a stained glass effect. She filled the fully al greenhouse with plants, selling it to a private buyer via social media.Back at his home in Elphinstone, a delighted George received pound from the sale, which he planned to give to his two sons.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were very pleased that the programme chose to visit our recycling centre, which provides a valuable service to local residents.The programme can be viewed at bbc programmes mvl

story: A DISTRESSING story made the front page of the East Lothian Courier on May , .Cruel-hearted teenagers are using baby birds on the River Tyne at Haddington for target practice, it was claimed title: mary-contini-column-a-tsunami-infections-youth-unless-vaccine-rollout-speeds
story: With vision and endurance, they sowed the inspiration that has resulted in a unique market of excellent tourism, food production and export that has shone a spotlight on Scotlandrsquos incredible natural larder.We have all benefited: businesses, customers, visitors and not least the tax man, as the industry contributes millions to the public purse and provides employment of upwards of eight per cent of the population.In over a year of crippling Covid restrictions, our trade has been severely impacted. Many businesses have been left so much in debt they are on the edge of collapse.Now, as the longed-for hope to reopen fully lies tantalisingly ahead, the very real threat of a new, more virulent iant virus has been identied.As hotels, pubs and restaurants are opening our doors, our teams now face a daily, hourly threat of infection from an innocent, unwitting carrier of this dangerous infection.This is not a horror movie. This is real le!Amazingly,  per cent of Scots over  have had their first, lesaving vaccination and as many as  per cent are fully protected with their second jab.The over-s in the population are thankfully next on the list.However, of the youngest cohort, --year-olds, less than  per cent have had a first vaccination.Hospitality is staffed by the highest proportion of young people in the country and, as they are now unprotected and working in a more relaxed environment, they are most vulnerable to infection.So, a plea to Government. title: dave-berry-column-east-lothian-political-bellwether
story: Not only was it the only Labour seat to fall to the SNP at this monthrsquos election, but both second and third-place candidates became MSPs by dint of their high places on party lists for South Scotland.Despite proximity to Edinburgh, we have tended to be overlooked. Now, having three MSPs of parties totalling over  per cent of Holyrood, our voice should be stronger.On the other hand, the county can also be seen as a bellwether of national trends extending well beyond Scotland. From trends here, both the new make-up of the Scottish Parliament and the drubbing Labour received in the Hartlepool by-election could have been anticipated.Once,  years of Tory policies had made Scotland grumpy. A phalanx of Labour MPs were shown powerless to deflect this.Blairrsquos  landslide came by appealing to a new middle class and assumingthat Old Labour voters had nowhere  to go. Scotland was Old Labour, based around town hall bastions and minersrsquo welfares, rooted ndash as East Lothian ndash in former coalfields and heavy industries.Growth of affluence from the s onward created a new demographic sht towards the middle class. Edinburghrsquos spilled into East Lothian: West Windygoul and Sandersonrsquos Wynd in Tranent Appin Dive and Suthren Yett in Prestonpans. These new residents rarely voted Labour, let alone lsquokent his faitherrsquo.Conservatives, driven back to bastions like Gullane Hill, failed to exploit this. Local-focused campaigns by Lib Dems and SNP did and seized control of East Lothian Council.This pattern was repeated across central Scotland, decimating Labourrsquos lsquopayrollrsquo army of campaign workers, drawn from councillors and MP MSP staff.This let a buoyant SNP work lsquoLabour heartlandsrsquo with social democratic policies, leading to the  SNP landslide to a supposedly impossible Holyrood majority, from which Labour has yet to recover. Even the Tories, decimated and disheartened two decades ago, worked their way back into second place under Ruth Davidsonrsquos leadership.It appears lessons from Hartlepool have not been learned by Labour. Their lsquoRed Wallrsquo remains on course to follow Tranent and Haddington Labour Clubs and become red rubble.

title: musselburgh-couple-delighted-celebrate-diamond-wedding
story: John, from Fisherrow, known to his friends and colleagues as Ducky, worked in Bruntons Wiremill in Musselburgh, while June, from Gorgie, was a seamstress at Buchananrsquos in Edinburgh.They met at the dancing in the old Labour Hall which was situated above the police station on Musselburgh High Street.The week after, John, who entertains audiences by singing his favourite Scottish songs at parties and s, took June out on a date to the theatre to see Scottish singer Calum Kennedy.A fan of the works of Scotlandrsquos national poet Robert Burns, John, a past vice-president of the Newcraighall Poosie Nansie Burns Club, can recite the Bardrsquos works without looking at a book, much to the delight of his family, and is renowned for his talent in giving Address To A Haggis.Love Portobello Registry Office on May , , with Irene Dodds and George Hutchison as witnesses.The couple set up home at the Promenade in Musselburgh, where they lived until their family expanded, which saw high-voltage switch gear in substations.June was a home help in the community for more than  years looking after the older generation.Prior to her retirement, she worked at Adamwood nursing home at Ravensheugh Road, Musselburgh.John, who is well known is fishing and shooting circles, also collected the football pools coupons for  years for Littlewoods pools.John, , and June, , have four children ndash John, Andrew, Kathleen and Margaret ndash  grandchildren and  great grandchildren.The couple enjoyed a low-key diamond wedding celebration at their Galt Road home amidst the Covid- pandemic, with family members attending at intervals to share a slice of cake and cup of tea.This is in contrast from their usual celebrations, which would always involve a large gathering of family and friends title: musselburgh-lollipop-man-john-mclay-praised-one-kind
story: Popular John McLay, , who mans a crossing at Pinkie Road, near Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, goes the extra mile by wearing lsquocool characterrsquo socks and festive hats, turning into Santa at Christmas and buying a bunch of flowers each Friday to give to someone in the street in a bid to brighten up their day.Parent Kirsty Clark, who runs the after-school club, said: ldquoHe really is one of a kind, a truly caring and lovely man. When my mum and dad visit from Fe, he always chats to my dad about the footie and,hersquos not seen them visit in a while, he will ask after them. Hersquos got a heart of gold.ldquoItrsquos not just in his job that hersquos so great, itrsquos outside in the community too, said another.ldquoHe saw us one night in Tesco looking a bit frazzled. As we were at the checkout, he came back with a bottle of Prosecco for me and said: lsquoHerersquos something to brighten your night.rsquo Too sweet!Another parent said: ldquoEvery Friday, John buys a bunch of flowers and gives them to a random person in the street in the hope it will brighten up their day.ldquoHe really is just such a genuinely nice person inside and out.The pupils also praised Mr McLay.Robbie said: ldquoJohn helps us to cross the road and makes me laugh, hersquos really funny.And Eli added: ldquoThe lollipop man is very fun and funny, he makes me smile in the morning.While Milo said: ldquoHersquos amazing and hersquos the best.Cathy added: ldquoJohn is cool and kind. I like his socks.

title: movies-returning-brunton-musselburgh-week
story: From Wednesday, the theatre will resume its big screen movies and event screenings in Venue , with modications to ensure comfort and safety in line with Scottish Government regulations. Staff will be on hand to welcome the public and answer questions.The film Nomadlandgets the programme going on Wednesday.The move is based on Jessica Bruderrsquos eponymous book, with a cast populated by real-le nomads playing fictional versions of themselves.From Oscar and BAFTA-winning director Chloe Zhao, this drama is a look at a rare way of le, full of quiet joy, generosity and humility, with a leading performance from the Oscar-winning Frances McDormand as Fern.Embarking on a journey through the American West, Fern stores all her worldly possessions and begins a simpler existence in her kitted-out van on the road. Recently widowed and having lost everything during the recession, her rugged, un-rooted lestyle baffles her friends and family as she drives from place to place on the lookout for seasonal work. Though Fern must adapt to the trials and pains of nomad le, she also finds a sense of community in the open road, the wizened, expansive landscapes and her dedicated compatriots.Then, Ammonitewill be screened on Wednesday, June .Set on the Dorset coastline, British filmmaker Francis Leeexplores the le of British palaeontologist Mary Anning in this period romance starring Kate Winslet and Saoirse Ronan.Anningrsquos talented but often overlooked career as a fossil hunter has left her walking the shorelines alone. When the melancholic Charlotte Murchison arrives, entrusted into Anningrsquos care by her wealthy husband, a compelling connection overcomes their initial fears. Marrying an unexpected friendship with overwhelming passion, the two women seek to overcome their great sense of loneliness.Minariis the midweek movie on Wednesday, June .In this semi-autobiographical family portrait from director Lee Issac Chung, a young Korean-American family move from Americarsquos West Coast to farm an isolated patch of land in Arkansas. On a mission to provide for his family, Jacobrsquosyearning for the American Dream conflicts with his fractured relationship with his we, his restless children and his own uncertain promises. A story of family devotion, migration and a sense of belonging in lsquos America, the arrival of the spirited, chaotic grandmother Soonjashts the family dynamic once more.Full information about all these events can be found at thebruntonTickets can be purchased directly through The Bruntonrsquos website or via the new box office number   , open Monday to Saturday, am to pm, until further notice.

title: looking-back-iconic-bass-rock-history
story: Baldred, the East Lothian saint, is said to have founded a hermitage on the island around  AD, and the ruins of St Baldredrsquos Chapel still stand.The Bass Rock passed into the ownership of the Lauder family, who built a castle on the island and kept sheep as a source of nourishment.King James I used the Bass as a prison for his political enemies.In , King James IV visited the Bass as a guest of Sir Robert Lauder, staying in his castle. James VI also came to the Bass in  as a guest of a later Lauder he liked the island so much that he offered to purchase it, but here he was snubbed.During the reign of Charles II, the Bass became a notorious prison, mainly used for the Covenanters.As many as  of these religious dissidents were held on the island, under appalling conditions: there was a well that produced fresh water, but fresh meat was a scarcity and the fishy taste of the seabirds was a torment to the wretched prisoners.In , four Jacobite officers were imprisoned on the Bass but they successfully took over control of the island and ordered the garrison to depart. After reinforcements had been received, they withstood a siege of nearly three years, under trying conditions, before they surrendered with full military honours in May .The Bass later passed into the ownership of the Dalrymple family, to which it still belongs today.The Bass Rock lighthouse was constructed in  by the celebrated engineer David Stevenson, a cousin of Robert Louis. He made sure that parts of the old castle were demolished for the stone to be harvested to build the -metre lighthouse, which served its purpose well for many years to come.It was lit with gas derived from vaporised paraffin oil for many years, monitored by the lighthouse keeper.Since , when the lighthouse was converted to electricity and remotely controlled, the lighthouse keeper was no longer needed, and the Bass Rock has been without any permanent human resident.From his house lsquoRockstowesrsquo on Melbourne Road, the celebrated postcard artist Reginald Phillimore enjoyed uninterrupted views of the Bass Rock.He had a fascination with the island, visited it many times and wrote a guidebook that he published himself.The Bass Rock is home to the largest gannet colony in the world: , birds spend their summer residence here, having been in Africa for the winter.The gannet, or lsquosolan goosersquo as it was known in Phillimorersquos time, is a large and formidable-looking seabird, with a white body, a yellow neck and head, and black and white speckled wings and tail.The reason that much of the Bass Rock appears white from a distance is the sheer number of birds and their acrid droppings.The gannet hunts fish by ing headlong into the sea, as any visitor to the Bass Rock can observe at close range.The air is full of birds, which are squawking cacophonously, and the smell from their droppings is very noticeable.Phillimore made some beautul postcards featuring the Bass Rock gannets he is likely to have travelled to the island from Canty Bay or on a vessel from North Berwick, but nowadays access to the Bass can be arranged via the Scottish Seabird Centre.This is an edited extract from Jan Bondesonrsquos book R.P. Phillimorersquos East Lothian

title: letter-week-climate-forest-must-done-right
story: While doing this, Irsquod like to encourage the council to apply the mantra lsquoRight trees, right place, right reasonrsquo, or these trees and their future growth are doomed.We have all seen the damage that mono-culture planting can do to landscapes and wildle. Trees for this Climate Forest need to be native species that enhance bioersity, planted where they can thrive, connect isolated pockets of wildle and benefit our local communities.They should also be planted in a way that improves peoplersquos enjoyment of their neighbourhood, while capturing carbon, reducing pollution and mitigating flooding.The council should lead by example and take full advantage of its own parks, playing fields, school grounds, open spaces and verges to create wildle corridors of trees and hedgerows, while building a network of green spaces for the people of East Lothian to enjoy.The golfing community could also play a major role in this project.East Lothian will also need to sign up new development to a  per cent tree cover and make developers plant at least one tree per garden space created.This, along with boundary hedges and native flowering areas, should help achieve the councilrsquos ambitious carbon targets.The proposed Climate Forest must also take into account local communities and their much-loved large mature trees currently in situ.The landscape of our county is changing, letrsquos make it for the better with the right trees, in the right space for the right reason.T ProudfootVictoria RoadNorth Berwick

title: special-hand-crafted-bench-finds-home-longniddry-dean-woods
story: The oak dowel and beech bench was designed and hand carved by path warden Graham Pettigrew.The bench was installed in the woodland area with the help of East Lothian Council Countryside Rangers.The intricate design of the bench represents the countryside from the Lammermuirs to the coast, and the spalted insets resemble the pattern of East Lothianrsquos shorelines.Wood carver Graham said: ldquoWhen visiting Loch Garten Nature Reserve, we were inspired by the design of a seat there which showed the landscape of Scottish pines on mountain slopes.ldquoI wanted to design and make a seat which was similarly fitting for our own local environment and seemed to grow out of it and feel part of it.Since retirement, Graham has carved items for enjoyment.He added: ldquoI designed the seat at the end of last year to be made from Scottish larch, sourced from Drem sawmills, and spalted beech which was found with permission after tree-felling in Gosford Estate.ldquoThe seat is held together by oak dowels and construction took around two months.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe council is very proud of the work carried out by Graham Pettigrew in designing, making and installing the new bench, which was done in consultation with the Countryside Ranger Service.ldquoThe seat provides visitors to the Dean a place to rest for contemplation or just to enjoy the surrounding woodland and nature.Graham and his we Maxine are both path wardens for Longniddry Dean woods.Their hope is that the new seat will provide a place for reflection in a location that is often bathed in sunlight.One Facebook user said: ldquoThis is an absolutely stunning bench. I love walking through the Dean Woods, it is so relaxing ndash I will be heading there for a peek today.Another added: ldquoWhat a wonderful idea to have a bench there.

title: bridge-centre-haddington-preparing-reopen-groups-use
story: The Bridge Centre, which is used by organisations ranging from mother and toddler groups to the University of the Third Age, has been closed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Now, furloughed staff are ing with immediate effect to prepare the premises in line with Covid- secure measures.The first groups toto the centre, on Haddingtonrsquos Poldrate, will be priority groups that provide key or essential support to the community.More groups willthroughout May, with the aim, subject to any change in coronavirus restrictions, of being fully open for groups of all ages toto their activities by the start of the autumn term.Jenny Harper, chairwoman of the Lamp of Lothian, which owns the Bridge Centre ndash which was being used by up to , people a week before the pandemic ndash said that the buildings had been ldquoeerily quiet.She said: ldquoThe Lamp of Lothian Trust are delighted that the Bridge Centre and their activities will be reopening slowly but surely in the next few weeks and months, and I am fully aware of the caution and care the staff have been taking.ldquoThe buildings have been, like so many, eerily quiet, but that is not to say much has not been happening behind the scenes.ldquoThe Lammermuir Larder volunteers are offering a wonderful service to the community, as well as the Bridge Centre outreach team.ldquoWe have welcomed the Tyneside Tavern into the courtyard, opening when permitted and dovetailing with the Bridge Centre.ldquoHaddington House is fully let to local businesses and nearly all are ing to their inidual offices.ldquoThe Lamp continues to shine its light in the local community and we fully intend to extend our charitable operations as le s to normal this year.ldquoI would like to thank all our Friends of the Lamp and Trusts who have continued to support us, and to our tenants in Haddington House.ldquoThese incomes enable us to offer all the buildings at the Poldrate free, to the community and for the community.Although the Bridge Centre has been closed, the staff have not been idle.Online youth classes and music lessons have been taking place, while the community outreach team, along with the community wardens and police, have been out every weekend since June last year.Christmas and Easter appeals have been organised, while the Lammermuir Larder, which provides a local community food initiative set up to support people struggling financially, was established in February.The closure has also given the opportunity to see ldquomuch-needed maintenance carried out in the building.

title: iceland-costa-apply-signs-haddington-retail-park-moves-closer-opening
story: Two planning applications for signage relating to stores at Haddington Retail Park are with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Iceland Foods Ltd is looking to put signs on the front of its building, which will contain The Food Warehouse, which is the furthest west unit of the main building at Gateside.Meanwhile, Costa Limited is seeking permission for ious signage at its drive-thru coffee shop off the B.Aldi and Home Bargains will also be part of the retail park.

title: plans-bring-relay-life-event-dunbar-first-time
story: The Relay for Le event, which collects money for lesaving research, is set to be staged outside the townrsquos Hallhill Sports Centre next summer.A final date for the fundraiser, which would be coming to Dunbar for the first time, has not yet been confirmed but organisers are in early discussions with the representatives of the sports centre on Kellie Road.Carrie Lennon, Cancer Research UK relationship manager, is among those hoping to take part in the fundraiser, with the town close to her heart.Her uncle Greig Hannan , who was a talented musician and postman in Dunbar, was just  when he died in September  from kidney cancer.The dad-of-three, who played lead guitar in Setting Sons, a classic punk covers band, lived on the townrsquos Ash Grove and had also played football for Dunbar United and Cockburnspath FC.Carrie said: ldquoIrsquoll be lighting my own candle at Relay for Le Dunbar in memory of Greig and for other loved ones in my family who have been through cancer.ldquoWe are looking ahead to summer  with great hope and excitement.ldquoRelay for Le is an inspirational event.One of the most poignant parts of the Relay for Le event is the Candle of Hope ceremony, which take place as darkness falls and lights up the venue with dedicated candles, honouring every le touched by cancer.Candle bags are decorated and dedicated to loved ones lost to cancer, a friend or family member living with the disease, those who have survived, or hope for the future ndash a world where all cancers are cured.The ceremony is a chance for quiet remembrance, reflection and celebration.Carrie added: ldquoThe Candle of Hope ceremony is the only time that the relay stops as we come together as a community to honour everyone who has been affected by cancer, united in the belief that our fundraising is making a dference and that we will beat cancer.ldquoWersquod love for some more people to come forward to help shape and create this amazing event.ldquoDunbar, are you ready to relay During the relay event, team members take it in turns to walk around a track to show their solidarity in the fight to beat cancer, while a iety of stalls, games and music from performers provide entertainment.Members of the public interested in taking part in the event and raising funds for the charity are being invited to come forward.A new fundraising committee will be formed to make the East Lothian event a success.Every year, about#,#people are diagnosed with cancer in Scotland and one in two people#in the UK born after #will get cancer in their#letime.Cancer survival in the UK has doubled since the s and Cancer Research UKrsquos work has been at the heart of that progress.But more funds and supporters are needed.To find out more about how you can get involved in Relay for Le Dunbar, email Carrie.Lennon@cancer.org.uk

title: dunbar-schoolboy-parts-foot-hair-good-cause
story: Ansel Parkin has already unicycled and run his way to raising hundreds of pounds for East Lothian Foodbank and Comic Relief.Now, the Dunbar Primary School pupil has said goodbye to his long locks to boost the Little Princess Trust.Proud mum Kirsty told the Courier: ldquoHe is loving his new hair.ldquoSometimes he says that he misses his long hair but he really enjoys his new hair.ldquoHe has noticed his hair is growing exceptionally fast!The -year-old had been growing his hair for about two years ldquomostly because he could not decide on a haircut.His mum said that the youngster wanted to have it cut while in primary seven and also to mark the end of lockdown.On April , he made the trip to Jack and Ivy on Dunbar High Street for the change of style.Neighbour Aimee Muirhead was given the honour of chopping the Dunbar youngsterrsquos locks, which have been sent off to the Little Princess Trust.The charity provides real-hair wigs for youngsters who have lost their hair through cancer or due to other illnesses.A minimum of seven inches of hair is needed to make a wig, with donors urged to raise money and send their hair to the good cause.Kirsty, who lives in Dunbar with husband Dan and Anselrsquos brother Ebon, , said: ldquoAnselrsquos hair had become so long that it was actually at the end of lockdown that it seemed as good a time as any to mark it and do some fundraising.ldquoYou have to donate over six inches and his hair was probably I think about  centimetreslong and he had about  centimetrescut off.Ansel, who last spring unicycled  miles for East Lothian Foodbank alongside his brother, also raised more than pound through an online fundraising page.Then, earlier this year, he swapped one wheel for lacing up his running shoes in aid of Comic Relief.He was joined by classmate Jake Page in running a mile every hour for  hours.Jake was dressed as superhero lsquoThe Flashrsquo, while Ansel donned a pair of butterfly wings for the occasion.To support Ansel, go to uk.virginmoneygiving KirstyParkin

title: ross-high-rugby-club-delighted-newly-refurbished-gym
story: Found in the club on Blawearie Road, the new facility is currently open to adult players, who can take part in activities in line with the current coronavirus regulations and those set out by the Scottish Rugby Union.It is also hoped that, in future, youngsters from the townrsquos Recharge facility could have access to the gym.Ross Highrsquos players have not been able to fully train for seven months due to Covid rules, with restricted training taking place since April.Players have only now been able to resume regular training, the first time since November.Called the Chris Miller Fitness Suite after the clubrsquos long-time player and the projectrsquos major sponsor, the gym contains several weight benches, racks, weights, a bike machine, and two other weight machines.There is also a personal best board for players to mark and record their performance.A dumbbell rack will be the last piece of equipment installed, still to be purchased by the club.Almost all of the equipment was brand new, with the old second-hand pieces that used to be in place now no longer fit for purpose and not suitable for rugby.The gym, found near the changing facilities, is decorated in the clubrsquos colours.Work took place over seven months. The old gym was stripped bare, the walls painted, a new ventilation and sound system installed and new flooring put in.The club raised more than pound, in sponsorship from members, players, coaches and sponsors to help make the project a reality, while the Walk With Scott Foundation ndash whose founder, the late Scott Glynn, was the clubrsquos former president ndash and East Lothian Council also helped bring the gym to le.Due to Covid restrictions, players have to book a slot beforehand.Ryan Strachan, Ross Highrsquos rugby and business officer, said that with the season the club had had, the new gym was some good news.He added: ldquoA huge amount of work has gone into this project from initial fundraising, socially distanced work from a small group of volunteers and now organising safe re-opening for players using an online booking system.ldquoOn behalf of the club, a big thanks to our sponsors, contributors, the small group of highly committed volunteers and our suppliers.ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for membership and people wanting to help, we wouldnrsquot be able to do a lot of things.Younger players will be able to access the gym in due course in cooperation with Active Schools, while those who attend the townrsquos Recharge could also soon be able to use it.

title: new-colouring-book-east-lothian-reveals-rich-history
story: A History of East Lothian Colouring Book is a heartfelt tribute to the unique heritage of the county.The illustrations ndash based on the history of East Lothian ndash include the Roman Temple of Mithras at Musselburgh, the Siege of Haddington and detailed images of Scottish coastal industries.The book is being sold to raise funds for the Waggonway Project, which runs a heritage centre in Cockenzie celebrating the history of Scotlandrsquos first railway.Cockenziersquos Alan Braby, a founding member of the group and illustrator of the book, spoke about his new publication.He told the Courier: ldquoAs an archaeological illustrator living in East Lothian, the history, archaeology and local scenery is outstanding.ldquoIn my reconstruction drawings, I have always tried to include it all, from early prehistory to the unknown, but I have recently rediscovered events and incidents of the th and th centuries.ldquoFrom a large portfolio of images, we were able to select a few that gave a potted history of East Lothian that proved most suitable to this publication.The Waggonway Project was set up to protect and publicise the route of Scotlandrsquos first railway, the  Tranent-Cockenzie Waggonway.Ed Bethune, Waggonway Project chairman, was delight with the bookrsquos launch.He said: ldquoAlanrsquos work has been a big part of the success of the Waggonway Project since  and we are delighted to celebrate this by bringing his fantastic artwork to a wider audience of all ages.ldquoThe book is greatyou want to add colour, or evenyou just want a collection of superb archaeological reconstruction to admire, and we are very grateful to Alan for his generosity in donating the proceeds to our community heritage projects.Alanrsquos book is available for purchase on the Waggonway website: waggonway product-page alan-braby-s-east-lothian-colouring-book

title: refurbishment-alterations-planned-cockenzie-primary-school
story: East Lothian Council is seeking permission to make alterations, including the demolition of a redundant chimney, at Cockenzie Primary School.The planning application, which is being considered by the local authorityrsquos planning department, outlines the work proposed.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council anticipated that the work could be carried out during the school holidays.She said: ldquoSubject to planning approval, work will be carried out at Cockenzie Primary School over the summer holidays involving major external refurbishment.ldquoThis includes flat roofing works, rooflight and window replacement, installation of an external insulated render system and the demolition of a redundant chimney.ldquoIn addition, internal works include an electrical rewire, new lighting and suspended ceilings to be undertaken to five classrooms.ldquoThis is part of a rolling programme of primary school project works and maintenance.

title: new-owners-taking-drummohr-caravan-park
story: International real estate advisor Savills, on behalf of private clients, has completed the sale of Drummohr at Levenhall, Musselburgh, to employee-owned leisure, retail and distribution specialist WCF Ltd for an undisclosed amount.Jo Ritzema, managing director of WCF Ltd, said this was the companyrsquos first caravan, camping and glamping site in Scotland, with the nearest being a five-star facility at Herding Hill Farm near Hadrianrsquos Wall in Northumberland.She stressed that the company hoped to go on to increase its portfolio of camping and glamping sites in southern Scotland and the north of England.The site is developed to accommodate  luxury holiday letting lodges, seven of which have hot tubs,  touring caravans, tents and motorhomes, together with  glamping units.The site also includes a storage area for up to  touring caravans, a three-bedroom bungalow with hot tub, two amenity blocks and a shop.The .-acresite is situated in the formerly walled gardens of a monastery and was converted to a holiday park in . It has been owned and run by the same family since .Mrs Ritzema first visited Drummohr as a camper herself, saying it benefited from the draw of Edinburgh and the ldquobeautul coastline and countryside of East Lothian.She said that the company, which has its registered office at Brampton, near Carlisle, had started an external refurbishment programme at Drummohr involving painting and decorating, with further plans to ldquoupdate and upgrade the facilities such as lodges and glamping units.She said that the site had a large touring area for tents and caravans which would also be improved, with the amenity blocks, accommodating showers, toilets and laundry, refurbished. It was also planned to add an indoor area including a kitchen for campers.Mrs Ritzema added that, given the ldquosignicant growth in glamping, additional units would be provided subject to consultation and the necessary planning consents.She added that the seven staff members, one of them part-time, who worked at the site had been retained, with a recruitment process under way for a further three or four new employees.They either live on-site or in the local area, including Angie Purves, an East Lothian resident who has been promoted from office manager to take over the running of Drummohr.Mrs Ritzema said that everyone involved in the venture was ldquomadly excited by it all and added that a new website for the site would highlight local visitor attractions.Richard Prestwich, director in the leisure and trade team at Savills, said: ldquoHoliday parks have become exceptionally sought-after due to the growing trend for staycations. It is encouraging to witness new entrants, such as WCF, targeting the holiday parks market and competing with the existing multi-park owners that have traditionally dominated the marketplace.

title: josh-taylors-fiancee-danielle-murphy-ecstatic-win---hoping-start-wedding-planning
story: Danielle Murphy watched the fight from home in Haddington after Covid- restrictions prevented her from flying to Las Vegas.Josh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed world championDanielle told the Courier: ldquoI am absolutely ecstatic about his win, he has made history."All the hard work, dedication and years that he has put into his craft have paid off.ldquoI was gutted not to fly over, there have been other times when he has gone away and we havenrsquot been able to be there but with the magnitude of this fight, everyone wanted to be there to support him, but we were all cheering him on and screaming for him at the television.Danielle said the Taylor family are excited to celebrate when the world champion touches down in Scotland today , but Covid- restrictions are making it dficult.She said: ldquoWe are having to play it by ear because it is hard to book anything."Normally we would go into a hall or celebrate in a pub but there are only so many people you can have in aand there is no way you could only pick  people to celebrate, so we arenrsquot doing that.ldquoWe are hoping to be able to get an open-top bus for him, but we need to seethe council will allow that.Danielle was disappointed by the lack of national televised coverage of the fight.She said: ldquoIt is absolutely shocking that the fight wasnrsquot broadcast on a bigger  for others to be able to watch.ldquoThe older generation do not have smartphones, so they were struggling to watch it when it was on because it was streamed through an app."Danielle said Josh was flying home on Tuesday for some well-deserved time off.The couple got engaged in Dubai last December.Danielle said: "Hopefully he can take some time off so we can get our wedding planned and chill for a while."

title: picture-gallery-duke-duchess-cambridge-visit-heavy-sound-cockenzie
story: William and Catherine, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, were in Cockenzie yesterday as part of their ongoing tour of Scotland.The couple were visiting Heavy Sound, which works with the Scottish Violence Reduction Unit , a joint project backed by the police and the Scottish Government which tries to tackle the root causes of violence.During the visit, the Duke and Duchess saw young people doing martial arts, music production and bicycle maintenance, organised by community organisation Heavy Sound, which is based at the Cockenzie Hub on Edinburgh Road.Manager Thilo Pfander persuaded Kate to try her hand at making some EDMand at first the Duchess received some encouragement from her husband, who said: "Yeah, drop a beat in the background."Kate did produce a bass-heavy track but added a piercing synth sound over the top.William laughed and said: "Whats that "It sounded like a cat... It might catch on ndash in about a hundred years time!"After a few moments, William pleaded for it to stop,saying: "Its hurting my ears."He then added: "Im not sure its number one material yet."

title: spectators-welcomed-musselburgh-racecourse-afternoon
story: The East Lothian track will admit  pre-booked race spectators at noon todayin the first step towards resuming normal racing.The racecourse worked carefully with East Lothian Councils Safety Advisory Group to establish a raceday protocol ahead of the event.Alcohol and food can only be ordered but must be consumed at tables in a designated picnic area, while a two-metre distancing rule will be enforced throughout the course.Musselburgh Racecourse said in a post on Facebook today: ldquoThe track is in great condition today. Were thrilled to welcome back spectators for the first time since February !The sold-out event will host eight races, with the first beginning at .pm.The next spectator event at the Musselburgh track is The Edinburgh Cup Raceday on Saturday, June .Musselburghs popular Stobo Castle Ladies Day has been moved from August  to August  to give spectators the best chance of relaxed Covid- rules.For a full fixture list and to book tickets, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: national-lottery-scrapped-newsagents-new-licence
story: Newsagents are worried a new operator would want to accelerate online and app sales which could prove disastrous for local convenience stores.The Gambling Commission is set to announce whether Camelot will keep hold of the licence for a fourth term in the next six months.And according to The Grocer, nearly half of convenience retailerssay the National Lottery is more important to their business than ever.Sisal, Allwyn, Sugal  Damani and Camelot are currently in contention for the new licence, with Richard Bransonrsquos Virgin Group and Northern  Shell other companies rumoured to be applying., retailers across the UK currently work with Camelot, earning around % commission on each draw-based game.Jason Birks, deputy VP at the National Federation of Retail Newsagents , said: ldquoCurrently, the National Lottery does have an online presence but Irsquove heard that some of the bidders want to do a lot more online and from a high street point of view, and from the point of view of community-based retailing, we need to protect bricks and mortar.ldquoThose in government need to not only view online as the lsquotrendyrsquo thing to do but bear in mind that people still like to visit bricks and mortar retailing.One independent retailer told The Grocer: ldquoI donrsquot think Camelot deserve another licence as for the last few years they have been very average with limited innovation, mediocre support for retailers with too much red tape.ldquoA new licensee should create a fresh approach and more energy.A Camelot spokesperson said National Lottery retailers earned around pound, in commission on average in  .A statement read: "We fundamentally believe that The National Lotterys success ndash which culminated in record sales last year ndash is reliant on building and maintaining a healthy retail channel."Thats why weve invested heavily in retail at the same time as growing the largest digital lottery channel in the world by revenuehellip"While were unable to share specic details of our bid, we can say that Camelots philosophy remains the same ndash with retail being a cornerstone of our strategy. National Lottery retailers have been fantastic partners to us over the past  years and, as theyve always been there for us, they can expect our continued support."

title: heros-welcome-josh-taylor-boxer-arrives-home-prestonpans
story: Proud residents gathered outside the Prestoungrange Gothenburg to welcome home their own Tartan Tornado after he beat his American rival Jose Ramirez in Las Vegas this weekend.Josh was crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the world on Saturday after a stunning unanimous points victory.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the worldDedicated fans braved the cold and rain to catch a glimpse of the world champion as he arrived home.Josh, accompanied by his fianceacutee Danielle Murphy, slowed his car to soak in the adulation of the crowd that had gathered outside his local pub.One of the first to greet the heroic boxer was his dad, James .Diane Taylor, Joshs mum, said she was overwhelmed seeing her son again as he ed home from his history-making win.She added: "I feel absolutely amazing."The energy of him driving through was amazing because I was panicking there wasnt going to be anybody here because of a mix-up with the flights and everything, but when I saw everybody I was so pleased, it is brilliant."The crowd erupted into cheers and chants as the champion drove down High Street at pm.Lara Connerton and Kenny Ainslie came out to celebrate Joshs arrivalOne resident, Lara Connerton, said: "I am super proud, it is absolutely amazing."He stopped and spoke to everyone and he took photos with the children in the streets."He is absolutely lovely, a top guy.""We are going to go and have a pint to celebrate."Another, Kenny Ainslie, said: "Its lovely seeing him, we are so proud."The Courier was live from Prestonpans when Josh arrived ndash watch a short video of his arrival here.

title: heading

title: lone-swan-finds-new-love-river-esk-musselburgh
story: Bonnie was taken to a new home on the River Esk when she abandoned her nest at Figgate Park, Portobello, after losing her partner Clyde.It appeared he had been in a fight with another male swanand had to be put to sleep.Sarah Auldsmith, Scottish SPCA senior animal rescue officer, said: ldquoWe were contacted back in April about an injured swan at Figgate Park.ldquoIt appeared a resident male swan, Clyde, had been in a fight with another male, resulting in a leg injury that made him unable to walk.ldquoClyde had also had bad arthritis for a number of years, which had been slowly getting worse.ldquoThis, coupled with him now being completely unable to stand, meant that he would not recover and the dficult decision was made to put him to sleep to end his suffering.She explained that Bonnie abandoned her nest about a month after losing Clyde.ldquoShe had been doing her best to incubate them but without her partner, and with her constantly being attacked by the new male, the eggs were unfortunately not viable, said Sarah.ldquoBonnie was moved to Musselburgh a couple of weeks ago and seems to be getting on well in her new environment.ldquoWe havenrsquot heardshersquos found a new mate yet but this is certainly a possibility as swans will often take up with another partner after their previous one has passed away.ldquoWhen she moved, Bonnie left her eggs in the nest and they have most likely been predated on since then.Photographer Angus Bathgate, from Wallyford, captured Bonnie on camera enjoying her new le on the Esk and it is thought she may have even have found love again, after being snapped with a new admirer.Mr Bathgate said that during a visit to the Esk, he was told by someone who was involved with the welfare of the swans that Bonnie could be singled out by the identication number on her tag.He added: ldquoIt made my day when Bonnie and her new mate chose to show their bonding together, which I captured on camera.Sarah appealed to the public: ldquoIf you discover any injured wildle, please contact our helpline on   .
